message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including waddling gait, calf enlargement, and absent reflexes, are suggestive of Duchenne muscular dystrophy. The best next step to confirm the diagnosis is genetic testing, which can identify mutations in the DMD gene that cause this disease. Electromyogram, muscle biopsy, and serum creatine kinase level can also support the diagnosis, but genetic testing is more specific and definitive.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest Duchenne muscular dystrophy, which is caused by a mutation in the dystrophin gene. Genetic testing is the best next step to confirm the diagnosis. Electromyogram and muscle biopsy may be helpful in evaluating neuromuscular disorders, but genetic testing is the most definitive method. Serum creatine kinase level may be elevated in muscular dystrophy, but it is not specific enough to confirm the diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and physical examination findings suggest Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD). Genetic testing is the gold standard for diagnosing DMD, and can confirm the diagnosis in up to 95% of cases. Muscle biopsy and serum creatine kinase level can also provide diagnostic information but are not as specific as genetic testing. Electromyogram may show myopathic changes but is not diagnostic for DMD.
